Over the past 2 decades, I've played quite a few games, and each one carried a certain feeling or emotion that has always stayed with me ever since. It's like going on a field trip at school, thinking back on it brings back memories, stories, adventure, fun; a collection of simple yet heartwarming thoughts. Half-Life 2 is like your first awkward kiss, it was weird, it was confusing, it was special, it was lovely, and it was something that you'll never forget.
Half-Life 2 is a puzzle-shooter that carries on the storyline from the original Half-Life game made in 1998, where you play as the most terrifying physicist that knows the exact velocity it takes to cave in a heavily armored human skull with a crowbar and you have to save the world from a dystopian nightmare of a authoritarian alien big brother invasion of Earth. Sounds simple, right?
Well you won't just have your trusty crowbar with you, oh no, you are a walking one-man arsenal. You can carry and utilize multiple weapons and tools in order to combat the plethora of enemies that you'll have to face. Headcrabs and Antlions that will leap at your face, the Combine soldiers that forever try to hunt you down, to the Zombies, Manhacks, Tripmines, Hoppers, and Striders, this game will throw everything in the mixed Chex Mix bag of the Combine at you in this game. But just as varied as the enemies that you'll face, so too are the ways you can dispatch them, from the Gravity Gun, SMG, Shotgun, Rocket Launcher, Energy Rifle, Grenades, and not to mention all of the environmental hazards to be used to your advantage!
And what if I told you that combat is only 1/3 of the entire game? The rest is attributed to the absolutely beautiful storytelling that this game provides through dialogue, nonverbal environmental storytelling, and atmosphere. A million stories could be told through text and speech, but the Half-Life series does what few games can manage to do, which is to guide and tell the player what to do and what is happening through level design and atmosphere alone. I have never seen a game where you [i]just know[/i] where to go with out some sort of tutorial or way that the game explicitly tells you. 
The other aspect of this Valve-made masterpiece is the ingenious puzzle-solving. The physics engine and how objects interact with each other in this run-down, beautifully chaotic would are intuitive and expertly laid out before you. The classic "We Don't Go To Ravenholm.." chapter is a perfect example of the genius (and somewhat demented) puzzles and traps to either avoid or utilize against the multiple enemies you'll find there. This game keeps you on your feet and attentive to any and every detail so that the puzzles can be solved naturally with just enough brainpower to challenge and not frustrate the player. And it is with these three pillars of ingenuity that really make this game shine above all others.
This is a beautiful game to play for anyone at all, absolutely everyone should play this game at least once.
Damn, This is a great game... I hope they make another one soon..

9/10
"The fries (inhale) are mine... Mr. Freeman...
The fries... are mine...

Not that i wish to imply that you were, sneaking towards... my fries. No one is more deserving of a snack, and all the ketchup in the world would have gone to waste until… well… let's just say my hunger has come again. The right fry in the wrong dip can make all the difference… in the world. So, wake up, Mr. Freeman. Wake up and… pass the salt." - The G-Man (probably)
